[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The wrist appears to be a human wrist joint that has been dislocated. Human wrist bones are composed of eight carpal bones that connect the hand to the forearm. The wrist joint has significant stiffness due to ligaments and tendons, but also has natural flexibility for movement. When dislocated, there is abnormal positioning of these bones relative to each other.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity will be pulling down on the wrist/hand. The patient's arm is resting on what appears to be a table surface, providing support. The main resistance will come from muscle tension, swelling, and the misaligned joint surfaces.
- The relevant object is the human wrist which has an effective mass of approximately 0.5 kg (considering the hand portion being manipulated), and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.8.
- The surface of interaction is the joint surfaces within the wrist which have cartilage and synovial fluid, creating a low friction interface with a coefficient of approximately 0.01 when properly aligned.
- Contact Types: The robot must maintain a secure but gentle grasp on the wrist while applying directional force. The grasp should be firm enough to manipulate but not so tight as to cause additional injury.
- Motion Type: Setting a dislocated wrist typically involves a combination of gentle traction (pulling) along the axis of the forearm, followed by specific directional pressure to guide the displaced bones back into their normal anatomical position. This may require slight rotation combined with linear motion.
- Contact Considerations: The robot must maintain secure contact with the wrist throughout the procedure while applying controlled forces in multiple directions. Downward pressure may be needed to stabilize the arm while longitudinal traction and rotational forces are applied.
- Motion along axes: The robot will exert a combination of linear and rotational motion along the wrist's x, y, z, rx, ry, and rz axes, with primary focus on linear traction along the x-axis (pulling outward), followed by downward pressure (z-axis) and slight rotation (primarily around y-axis).
- Task duration: Based on standard manual reduction techniques, this procedure should take approximately 5-10 seconds of steady, controlled motion.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Wrist mass: 0.5 kg, Grip friction coefficient: 0.8, Joint surface friction: 0.01, Required traction force: 20-30 N
- Relevant equations: F = m×a (for acceleration), F_friction = μ×N (for friction forces), Torque = F×r (for rotational forces)
- Relevant assumptions: The patient's muscles are relaxed, the joint is not severely swollen, and there are no fractures present. The dislocated joint will follow the path of least resistance when proper forces are applied.
- Computations: To overcome muscle tension and joint resistance, we need approximately 20-30 N of traction force. For stabilization, approximately 10 N of downward force is needed. For rotational guidance, approximately 1-2 N·m of torque is required.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 0.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.8 along the surface: The force required to overcome friction is F = μ×N = 0.8×(0.5 kg×9.8 m/s²) ≈ 4 N. Additional force is needed to overcome joint resistance and muscle tension.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need for longitudinal traction to create space between joint surfaces, the robot must exert negative force along the X-axis with magnitude 25 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need for slight lateral alignment to guide the carpal bones, the robot must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 5 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to stabilize the joint and guide the bones downward into proper alignment, the robot must exert positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude 10 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the minimal need for pronation/supination during this specific reduction, the robot must exert no torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need for slight flexion to guide the carpal bones back into position, the robot must exert clockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 1.5 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need for slight ulnar deviation to align the joint surfaces, the robot must exert counterclockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0.8 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force: Estimated force range based on need to maintain secure grip without causing tissue damage or pain, thus 15 to 20 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist joint with 0.5 kg effective mass, friction coefficient of 0.8 with gripper, joint surfaces have 0.01 friction coefficient when aligned"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply longitudinal traction (negative x-axis) while providing downward pressure (positive z-axis) and slight lateral force (positive y-axis), combined with flexion (clockwise y-rotation) and ulnar deviation (counterclockwise z-rotation)"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-25, 5, 10, 0, -1.5, 0.8]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 15
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 8
```

[end of motion plan]

Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
